It crashed on Android 14. Sorry, there are no other useful information. The app uses AppCenter.Crashes for the crash reporting but this one has not been reported by it. I have report from Google Play only. Because of this, it's likely a startup crash before AppCenter is loaded and has a chance to report it, too.

### Steps to Reproduce

I'm not able to reproduce the crash lokally. I have just a crash report from Google Play Console.

### Link to public reproduction project repository

_No response_

### Version with bug

9.0.81 SR8.1

### Is this a regression from previous behavior?

Yes, this used to work in Xamarin.Forms

### Last version that worked well

Unknown/Other

### Affected platforms

Android

### Affected platform versions

Android 14

### Did you find any workaround?

No

### Relevant log output

```shell

```

nodes.author: rokmeglic71
nodes.body: In relevant [discussion](https://github.com/dotnet/maui/discussions/30433), somebody got more info using Sentry. Maybe a step forward for you?

nodes.author: holecekp
nodes.body: @rokmeglic71 Thank you for the link to the discussion. I'm using AppCenter.Crashes for the crash reporting. But it didn't reported anything (only Google Play itself reports it). This makes me believe that the crash happened on startup before the crash reporting library has a chance to catch it. I guess that the result would be the same with the Sentry, Unfortunatelly, it's not easy to try it in the production because it would mean that I would have to rewrite the privacy policy which is translated to about 20 languages.

nodes.author: rokmeglic71
nodes.body:
uf, privacy policy work, ught :)
OK, next possible option is [disabling garbage collection](https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/21479#issuecomment-2379126234) ... because you can not reproduce it, you [can not access the logs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/xamarin/android/deploy-test/debugging/android-debug-log?tabs=windows) which would be a nice addition to this error. Nice youtube video for saturday morning about [sigsegv and Maui - short under 2 minutes](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T_-HLq-gSEs). Maybe [focus on async Tasks](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/1639204/native-crash-reporting-got-a-sigsegv-while-executi)?

[I also found relevant issue](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/105389#issuecomment-2260713371), maybe you can learn something from it?

If nothing works, [here you have an example of Sentry report.](https://github.com/dotnet/android/issues/9055#issuecomment-2194672673).

nodes.author: baaaaif
nodes.body:
Has anyone experienced this primarily affecting Samsung devices? At least for us, it currently only affects one customer who uses Samsung devices.
And are you using SemaphoreSlim in your code?
Perhaps there's a connection to this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73044921/fatal-signal-11-sigsegv-code-1-segv-maperr-dotnet-maui-with-shiny-3-alp/73657147#73657147

I have now set AndroidEnableSGenConcurrent to false and removed the use of SemaphoreSlim and am curious to see how the crashes develop

nodes.author: holecekp
nodes.body:
@baaaaif It is affecting phones from multiple manufacturers (Samsung, Redmi, Google) and multiple Android versions. I cannot see any pattern in case of my app. I don't use SemaphoreSlim in my code.

Concerning the repro project, I will not be able to create one. This type of crash is relatively rare compared to other MAUI crashes. So it would be very hard to replicate it. I think it might be a duplicate of https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/21479. Probably there could be a bug in the GC. However, because the crash is rare, even if I would try different GC settings I wouldn't be able to tell reliably if it helped or not. I think that this issue can be closed as there is more discussion going on in https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/21479 and the subsequent https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/105389

nodes.author: PureWeen

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
Since, the crash looks to be completely inside `libmonosgen-2.0.so`, we can move this to dotnet/runtime.

We can use `ndk-stack` to get line numbers:
* Find the `libmonosgen-2.0.so` your app used, you could review a `.binlog` to find it.
* Run `dotnet-symbol` on the directory.
* Run `ndk-stack` on a log containing the crash.
* This can show you the line numbers in: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/tree/main/src/mono

I would post an example, but there isn't a recent one in my shell history.

author: JakeYallop
body: I have additional files that are produced at build time, so they cannot exist in the /wwwroot folder, that I want to output with the rest of my app. Non-WebAssembly SDK projects could use <WasmExtraFilesToDeploy> for this - what can be used for WebAssembly SDK projects?

nodes.author: dotnet-policy-service
nodes.body:
Tagging subscribers to 'arch-wasm': @lewing
See info in [area-owners.md](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/area-owners.md) if you want to be subscribed.
<!-- Policy app identification https://img.shields.io/static/v1?label=PullRequestIssueManagement. -->

nodes.author: JakeYallop
nodes.body:
Linking a workaround I've document in #117900.

Just adding the files as `<Content />` without any special handing does not work if those files are not within the wwwroot folder (and if they are in there, they'll be included anyway). Any Content files not in wwwroot are filtered out by the `ResolveProjectStaticWebAssets` target.

Instead, what I had to do was create a target that ran before `AssignTargetPaths` - this is the task that resolves `<Content />`, add them specifically at that point:

```xml
 <Target Name="_AddContent" BeforeTargets="AssignTargetPaths">
    <ItemGroup>
      <Content Include="MyContent.json">
        <! -- content configuration etc. -->
      </Content>
    </ItemGroup>
  </Target>
```

nodes.author: maraf
nodes.body:
Is it problematic to generate the files into `wwwroot` and just gitinore them?

cc @javiercn

nodes.author: JakeYallop
nodes.body:
Technically, that would work - however, I think its very surprising if I have

```xml
    <ItemGroup>
      <Content Include="package.json">
        <CopyToOutputDirectory>Always</CopyToOutputDirectory>
        <CopyToPublishDirectory>Always</CopyToPublishDirectory>
      </Content>
    </ItemGroup>
```

in my csproj, and it _doesn't_ get copied the output folder.

And, I'd now have to maintain that gitignore. Ignoring `wwwroot/` completely doesn't seem like a good solution (as users may have other files in wwwroot that they want to commit, although it would work for my specific case).

It would be nicer to find a solution that is more intuitive and easier to document than the workaround needed above (and of course, that workaround is not gauranteed to continue to work if the task execution order changes between updates), whether that's getting `<Content>` to work, or using an alternative property,

nodes.author: maraf
JakeYallop
nodes.body:
> The general problem is that the csproj contains all sorts of files.

Right - its totally fine if we don't end up using `Content`, as long as there is some kind of solution. Trying to copy over the files manually is a non-starter, when taking into account different output paths for build vs publish etc. If that solution is a custom MSBuild property, similar to WasmExtraFilesToDeploy, great, if not, then be nice to document whatever the solution might be - if that's "output the files into wwwroot", then that's fine.

title: WebAssembly SDK - what is the replacement for `<WasmExtraFilesToDeploy>`?

author: oakad
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

At some point, Firefox started to display the following deprecation warning for the Blazor wasm code:

> The WebAssembly exception handling 'try' instruction is deprecated and should no longer be used. Please recompile to use the 'try_table' instruction instead.

I suppose, dotnet wasm compiler still emits "legacy" exception handling code.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Don't expect to see any warnings from the browser.

Suppose, dotnet wasm compiler should be given an option to emit "new" exception handling code.

If such an option exists, it's really difficult to find.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: SingleAccretion

Yes, there is no option for this right now. We could introduce one, but it would complicate the build, so another possibility is "just" waiting a few years until the new EH becomes widely available everywhere.

nodes.author: oakad
nodes.body: Compilers usually have so many target related options, that one more is hardly going to complicate things that much. :-)

author: davidwrighton
body:
### Description

While fixing issue #104511 with PR #118413 to CoreCLR I've found that the new test I added continues to fail on Mono.

### Reproduction Steps

Run the src/tests/Loader/classloader/Statics/Regressions/SelfReferentialStatics/SelfReferentialStatics.csproj test under mono.

### Expected behavior

It should pass

### Actual behavior

It doesn't.

### Regression?

No

### Known Workarounds

Put the static field in a nested type or other unrelated type.

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: There needs to be more investigation but these issues look more like memory fragmentation than leaks.  RC1 should have some improvements in this area.

nodes.author: andrew-kulikov
nodes.body: It doesn’t appear to be fragmentation in this case, since memory usage grows continuously and there are no `free` calls for the addresses returned by `malloc`. Also, if by fragmentation you’re referring to https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/118044, I ran the same sample on a local WASM runtime build that includes the fragmentation fix, and observed no difference compared to preview4.

nodes.author: pavelsavara
nodes.body:
The stack trace points to `__cxa_allocate_exception` and so observing when `__cxa_free_exception` is (not) called could help us to understand this.

I would expect something like `mono_llvm_cpp_catch_exception` -> `__cxa_end_catch` -> `__cxa_decrement_exception_refcount` -> `__cxa_free_exception`.

The logic that `mono_llvm_cpp_catch_exception` is [expanded to ](https://gist.github.com/pavelsavara/f45fd93baa8b89046a36596fd09e0e19)

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/cff2063695fe8977164cc1be3866a64427c80db4/src/mono/mono/mini/llvm-runtime.cpp#L47-L49


- I wonder if I broke it by https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/111033
- How is `-s DISABLE_EXCEPTION_CATCHING=0` related
- I wonder how jiterp influences this, because it calls `mono_interp_invoke_wasm_jit_call_trampoline` -> `mono_jiterp_end_catch` -> `__cxa_end_catch` too
- Is there more about the topic in [emscripten](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aemscripten-core%2Femscripten%20__cxa_free_exception%20&type=code) ?
- should our `_Unwind_DeleteException`call `free` ?

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/cff2063695fe8977164cc1be3866a64427c80db4/src/native/external/llvm-libunwind/src/Unwind-wasm.c#L72-L80

@andrew-kulikov could you please try if it also leaks with `<WasmEnableExceptionHandling>false</WasmEnableExceptionHandling>`

nodes.author: andrew-kulikov
nodes.body:
I tried to specify `<WasmEnableExceptionHandling>false</WasmEnableExceptionHandling>` in the sample, but it seems to have no effect on both exceptions and task exceptions. 

Just to test I also tried to disable jiterpreter using
```js
dotnet
.withRuntimeOptions([
    "--no-jiterpreter-traces-enabled",
    "--no-jiterpreter-interp-entry-enabled",
    "--no-jiterpreter-jit-call-enabled",
])
```
, but it didn't help as well.

author: andrew-kulikov
body: ### Description I am porting a huge .NET application (a game written on a custom engine) to browser-wasm runtime. In release build we use AOT, and I noticed that in such configuration SBRK pointer slightly grows during app lifetime while managed heap size stays the same. Investigation with emscripten memory profiler helped me to find some problems, so listing them here. First problem: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/118526 The second is related to events in AOT build. I tested also without AOT, and the problem is not reproduced in a simple release build. Repo with reproduction samples can be found [here](https://github.com/andrew-kulikov/dotnetwasm-bench?tab=readme-ov-file#running-sample). Sample is named "Events". Task.Delay(16); } } ``` Top stack trace with GC after each iteration: ``` Allocation sites with more than 16 MB of accumulated allocations, or more than 100 simultaneously outstanding allocations: 6 author: carlreinke
body:
`dotnet.download()` can be used to download the assets, but there seems to be no way to access the downloaded assets.

Perhaps `download()` could give access to `getConfig()`?

**Background**
I am running .NET in an audio worklet, which has no ability to `fetch()` assets.  Right now I am loading the assets by proxying the fetch requests through the message port of the audio worklet (except for the .js assets, which are statically `import`ed since an audio worklet cannot use `import()`).  The main thread has already downloaded the assets for it's own instance of the runtime, so instead of fetching all the assets twice (hopefully the second time from cache, but no guarantees), I'd like to just download the assets once, send a copy of the assets across the message port (which will be used to instantiate the runtime there), and then instantiate the runtime in the main thread (which consumes the `buffer`s of the assets, so I cannot get them after `dotnet.create()` via `getConfig()`).

Of course, if there's a way I could copy the WASM modules to the audio worklet to avoid compiling them twice, that would be even better.

nodes.author: JakeYallop
nodes.body:
Would some way of being able to access the assets imported by the runtime within C# help here?

For my project, I need access to the dlls, which are already imported by the runtime. At the moment, I have to parse the config and re-`fetch` them (with the similar hope that they will be cached) . Being able to access the assets within C# directly would solve this for my issue, and would mean there would be no need for serialization or passing those additional buffers between runtimes.

`GetCurrentAssemblies()` isn't a suitable stand-in for this - the dlls haven't necessarily been used yet by that point (and trying to then get a buffer from an assembly is then a little complicated).

I was considering opening a new issue, but this seems like a similar problem.

title: [browser] Allow access to asset data after `dotnet.download()`

author: jamescrosswell
body:
### Apple platform

iOS

### Framework version

net9.0-*

### Affected platform version

net9.0-ios18.0 version 9.0.301 (workload version 9.0.301 also)

### Description

When building a .NET 9 MAUI application targeting iOS in release mode, `IsPortableCodeView` should be true in the `CodeView` debug directory entry. It appears to incorrectly return false since the `MinorVersion` is set to 0.

### Steps to Reproduce

Clone https://github.com/jamescrosswell/is-portable and follow the instructions in [the readme](https://github.com/jamescrosswell/is-portable/blob/main/README.md).

### Expected behaviour

`IsPortableCodeView` should be true for all of the assemblies. This should only be false for Windows PDB files (not relevant when running on iOS).

### Actual behaviour

`IsPortableCodeView` is showing as false for the PE file located at `MauiTestApp/obj/Release/net9.0-ios/iossimulator-arm64/stripped/MauiTestApp.dll`. This is problematic since this appears to be the assembly that is actually used when running the app on the iOS simulator (where we're also observing this issue in the [Sentry SDK for .NET](https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-dotnet)). 

Additionally the value of the `Stamp` differs from the `Stamp` in the accompanying PDB files (meaning symbolication is no longer possible). 


### Did you find any workaround?

Building with `/p:MtouchLink=SdkOnly` avoids the issue for application assemblies. This isn't really a workaround though. In the case of Sentry, that means we still won't be able to symbolicate stack frames from the SDK and may increase the size of our SDK users's applications when shipping these. 

### Relevant log output

_No response_

nodes.author: rolfbjarne
nodes.body: Setting EnableAssemblyILStripping=false in the csproj works around this, so it looks like it's a problem with the IL stripper (the [ILStrip](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/tasks/MonoTargetsTasks/ILStrip/ILStrip.cs) task) => moving to dotnet/runtime.

nodes.author: akoeplinger
jamescrosswell
nodes.body:
It's curious that this only started happening recently. I know the Age/Stamp in the PE Header matched those in the PDB for net9.0-ios apps built in release mode in the past... So something about how stripping is performed has changed recently.  

It looks like the last [change to the Cecil sources](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime-assets/commits/main/src/Microsoft.DotNet.CilStrip.Sources) was August 2024 😕 

There are more [recent changes to the ILStrip task](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/commits/main/src/tasks/MonoTargetsTasks/ILStrip/ILStrip.cs), but none that I can see that seem like they would cause a change in this behaviour.

nodes.author: akoeplinger
nodes.body:
> It's curious that this only started happening recently.

Hmm yeah that's strange since I can't see any change in that area either. Maybe confirm by installing an earlier build of net9 and the iOS workload.

title: IsPortableCodeView false in stripped assemblies on iOS

author: ilonatommy
body:
Backport https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/108582 to release/9.0-staging.

To reduce WASM test matrix
- remove pipelines
- remove `WasmTestOnNodeJS` scenario
- remove node based `Wasm.Build.Tests` tests
- Old Blazor_net50 project that was added in https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/56606 to be used in WBT but we started using different logic to test Blazor since then and it can be safely removed.

Leave untouched:
- `PlatformDetection.IsNotNodeJS`
   - HTTP & WS tests
   - Hybrid globalization tests
- detection in `src\mono\browser\test-main.js
- any production code


Contributes to https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/111753.
